hints.content:
Each student got $\purpleC3$ stickers.

Ms. Suarez gave out $\greenD{21}$ total stickers.

[[☃ image 1]]

How many $\blueD{\text{groups}}$ are there?

options.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal lengths, a first tape labeled 21 and a shorter second tape with one part labeled 3. A curved bracket across the bottom and the width of the first tape is labeled with a question mark and the words equal groups. !

hints.content:
We can write this as a multiplication problem. 

$\purpleC{\text{size of the group}}\times\blueD{\text{ number of groups}} = \greenD{\text{ total}}$

So, $\purpleC3\times\blueD{\text{?}} = \greenD{21}$

We can also write this as a division problem. 

$\greenD{\text{total}}\div\purpleC{\text{ size of the groups}}=\blueD{\text{ number of groups}} $

So, $\greenD{21}\div \purpleC3=\blueD{\text{?}}$

The equations that would help us find out how many students Ms. Suarez has are:

 - $\purpleC3\times\blueD{\text{?}} = \greenD{21}$
 -  $\greenD{21}\div \purpleC3=\blueD{\text{?}}$

question.content:
Ms. Suarez gave each of her students $3$ stickers.  She gave out a total of $21$ stickers.

**Which equations would help us find out how many students Ms. Suarez has?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
